contentrichtext.text: {{Taxobox | name = Red Wattlebird | status = LC | status_system = IUCN3.1 | status_ref = <ref name=IUCN2012>{{IUCN|id=106005386 |title=''Anthochaera carunculata'' |assessors=[[BirdLife International]] |version=2012.1 |year=2012 |accessdate=16 July 2012}}</ref> | image =Red Wattlebird Nov09.jpg | image_caption=Red Wattlebird feeding | regnum = [[Animal]]ia | phylum = [[Chordate|Chordata]] | classis = [[Aves]] | ordo = [[Passeriformes]] | familia = [[Meliphagidae]] | genus = ''[[Wattlebird|Anthochaera]]'' | species = '''''A. carunculata''''' | binomial = ''Anthochaera carunculata'' | binomial_authority = ([[George Shaw|Shaw]], 1790) }} The '''Red Wattlebird''' (''Anthochaera carunculata''), also known as '''Barkingbird''' or '''Gillbird''', is a [[honeyeater]]; a group of birds found mainly in [[Australia]] and [[New Guinea]] which have highly developed brush-tipped tongues adapted for [[nectar]] feeding. The tongue is flicked rapidly and repeatedly into a flower, the upper mandible then compressing any liquid out when the bill is closed. Although honeyeaters look and behave very much like other nectar-feeding [[passerine]]s around the world (such as the [[sunbird]]s and [[flowerpecker]]s), they are unrelated, and the similarities are the consequence of [[convergent evolution]]. The Red Wattlebird is a large (up to 35 cm) grey-brown honeyeater with red eyes, distinctive red [[Wattle (anatomy)|wattles]] either side of the neck and white streaks on the chest and belly, which reveals a bright yellow patch towards the tail. Juveniles are generally less flamboyant, with less prominent wattles and browner eyes.<ref>http://ozwildlife.awardspace.com/wildlifedetail.php?genus=Anthochaera&species=carunculata Entry at Oz Wildlife</ref> The species is found in SE [[Queensland]], [[New South Wales]], [[Victoria (Australia)|Victoria]], [[South Australia]] and southwest [[Western Australia]] in open forest, woodland, and near human habitation. The nest is formed from sticks and leaves lined with bark and hair, between 2 and 16 meters above ground, usually in the forked branches of a tree or shrub, in which two or three, pale brown-spotted pink [[Egg (biology)|egg]]s are normally laid. In addition to nectar, it takes insects and other small creatures, usually by [[hawking (birds)|hawking]], and also [[berry|berries]] and other fruit. This bird was first described by [[John White (surgeon)|John White]] in his ''Journal of a Voyage to New South Wales'' (1790).<ref name=IUCN2012/> ==Gallery== <gallery> File:Anthochaera carunculata.jpg File:Red Wattlebird.jpg|Feeding on ''Banksia'' sp. flower, [[Perth, Western Australia|Perth]] File:Redwattlebird2.jpg File:1A AustNativeBird0021.JPG|Top view File:Anthochaera carunculata -Australia-8-3c.jpg File:Red Wattlebird chick.jpg|Chick File:Red-Wattle-bird.jpg|Melbourne File:Red-Wattle-Bird-Feeding.jpg|Feeding File:Anthochaera carunculata - Australian National Botanic Gardens.jpg File:Red_Wattlebird_on_wooden_perch_in_Australia_2012.jpg|Showing Lemon-Yellow plumage </gallery> ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== {{Commons category|Anthochaera carunculata}} {{wikispecies|Anthochaera carunculata}} * [http://ibc.lynxeds.com/species/red-wattlebird-anthochaera-carunculata Red Wattlebird videos, photos and sounds] on the Internet Bird Collection. * [http://collections.tepapa.govt.nz/ObjectDetails.aspx?oid=537779 Holotype of the Red Wattlebird ''Anthochaera carunculata'' in the collection of the Museum of New Zealand Te Papa Tongarewa] [[Category:Anthochaera]] [[Category:Birds of South Australia]] [[Category:Birds of Western Australia]] [[Category:Animals described in 1790]]
